docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal advisory panel on Social Security ended its deliberations without coming to agreement on a plan to shore up the system's financial future. Instead it will present three different plans, none with majority support. Fortunately, a good plan can be stitched together from the best parts of two of the three plans. But the lack of consensus probably will delay the date that Congress solves the entire Social Security problem. The members did agree to invest Social Security taxes in stocks and other private securities, as well as the low-yield government bonds that are the only existing investment option. That change will make Social Security a better deal for workers. But the impact on the overall economy will be minor. The Social Security Trust Fund would substitute stocks for some of the bonds it used to buy from the Treasury. But the Treasury will then have to sell more of its bonds to private investors. The change is unlikely to affect how quickly the economy grows.
docs.abstract: Editorial says inability of Federal advisory panel on Social Security to devise means of shoring up system's financial future makes it likely that Congress will tinker and solve bankruptcy threat, but not address more subtle economic threat (M)
docs.snippet: A Federal advisory panel on Social Security ended its deliberations without coming to agreement on a plan to shore up the system's financial future. Instead it will present three different plans, none with majority support. Fortunately, a good plan...

docs.lead_paragraph: THIS village, its residents say, has a long history of caring. The Ossining Children's Center is currently celebrating its 100th anniversary; the Open Door Family Health Center here provided low-cost medical care to 7,500 Ossining residents last year, while other nonprofit groups concerned with food, affordable housing and child care served one-third of Ossining's population of 22,600 in 1995. But the intricate web of services that has helped people like Tasha Gonzalez, a 23-year-old single mother of twins, to work toward a better life may crumble under the impact of the country's new welfare law. Anticipating the chaos that may follow if social service agencies lose all or most of their Federal, state and county funds, representatives of eight of the agencies recently formed the Ossining Safety Net Committee.

headline.main: Ossining Agencies Unite to Gain a Stronger Voice for the Needy

docs.abstract: Eight anti-poverty and social-service agencies in Ossining, NY, unite, anticipating chaos that may follow if social service agencies lose all or most of their Federal, state and county funds under nation's new welfare law; photo (M)
